content.description:
Start just left of the small ledge and follow the obvious crack up to the anchors. Stay away from the easier holds on the 5.8 TR just to climber's right to make it a true 5.10.

Come around the corner from the 5.11/12 that pops you out at the main lookout and you'll find yourself in a cleared corner with a nice ledge. Just to the climber's right of this route is a 5.8 top rope route.
5 Bolts

Amazing face climb that pops out at you about 5 minutes after traversing the bottom of the cliffs. Sets of ledges give way to pocket pulling, powerful lockoffs and long reaches.

5 minutes down the trail at the base of the cliffs, it's new bolts as of 2017. First big obvious face that is north facing . Blank looking.
Bolts. No anchors on top actually creates a dilemma. I lowered off the top bolt (6 inches from top of cliff) and hiked around top to grab my top Quickdraw after I was done. Could possibly belay a second up on a tree.

**Warning: Poison Ivy is plentiful at the base of these cliffs. Please take extra caution when walking. The ivy is in leaves of 3 with berries and turns red in late summer. It leaves a nasty rash if contacted.***The East Cliffs is where the real magic of the Cup and Saucer hides. In a striking 90 degree angle, the Niagara Escarpment drops directly down in a pattern of corners, faces, and dramatic aretes. Most of the climbing takes place above the forest, making the location and exposure supreme. There is plenty of potential for new routes, with only 10 to 15 lines bolted over a sample platter of rock right now. The climbing itself is on seemingly blank rock, but the climber will find surprisingly good pockets and flat ledges. The corners are easy to moderate, and the faces are hard technical pocket climbing. The aretes are unbolted at this time, and are sure to become future ulta-classics once bolted. Difficulty ranges from 5.6 to 5.12.
